abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Municipal Development Project
            for Argentina had the following ratings: the outcome was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: Demand-driven portfolio operations
            such as the MDP-I and II are effective instruments to
            promote basic institutional development among municipal
            governments. Commitment from municipal authorities and
            personnel is important for the success of municipal
            strengthening projects. Demand-driven portfolio operations,
            such as the MDP-I and II, provide great flexibility and risk
            diversification, but the overall portfolio tends to be
            rather fragmented. An important role for subnational
            governments is critical to the success of the project. Keep
            subproject requirements within reasonable bounds. While the
            MDP-II operation was not targeted at poverty alleviation,
            this type of operation offers the opportunity to improve
            living conditions of the poor. Ensuring technical soundness
            of individual investments can be challenging in
            demand-driven operation of such a broad scope as the MDP-I
            and II. The vertical integration of the basic management
            tools at the provincial and municipal levels is critical to
            fully capitalize on their potential fiscal impact and ensure
            their sustainability over time. Provincial governments need
            to play a key role in the design and implementation of
            municipal development strategies. Dissemination has to be
            considered as an important activity at the onset of a
            project, and treated as such in terms of inputs, outputs,
            timetable, and impact. Demand-driven portfolio operations
            can serve as incubators, fostering the generation of
            innovative solutions for common problems. Decentralize all
            review, procurement, and disbursement procedures as much as
            possible. Do not expect municipal portfolio projects to
            disburse quickly and easily at first. Field visits to
            provinces and municipalities are necessary for the effective
            supervision of municipal projects.
